panes.content:
Great to see you!

This is the CodeNotary live playground!

It's easy to get started with immudb. To begin learning about immudb, select a topic from the list on the left. You can find all binaries used here on the immudb GitHub repository.

On certain pages, you'll find a code snippet or live environment loaded to the right of this guide.

You can run those code snippets to see their output below.

You can also inspect the Merkle tree that represents the current state of the embedded immudb database in a simplified way.

To clear the database and start from scratch, click the trash can icon in the upper right, or refresh the page.

Let's pick a topic to get started:

  • For more information on immudb, read "Introduction to immudb". This page will explain what immudb is and why you want to use it.
  • "Getting started with immuclient" is all about the command line interface. This section will teach you how to use immuclient to login to immudb and begin performing basic transactions.
  • "Programming with the SDKs". This section will teach you how to interface with immudb via the Python SDK. immudb has more SDKs available (Java, Golang, and Node.js) and we'll cover these in the playground over time.

immudb - the database

immudb is a key-value database with built-in cryptographic proof and verification that is tamper-evident. Data is never overwritten or deleted, and the complete change history is kept intact.

Client-cryptographic proof

The complete data integrity is additionally cryptographically protected by the clients (CLI, SDK, applications), removing the need to trust the server.

versus traditional databases

While the transactions and logs of traditional databases, are hard to scale and are mutable (so there is no way to know for sure if your data has been compromised), immudb is immutable.

You can add new versions of existing records, but never change or delete records. This lets you store critical data without fear of it being changed unnoticed.

versus Blockchain

Data stored in immudb is cryptographically coherent and verifiable, just like blockchains, but without all the complexity. Unlike blockchains, immudb can handle millions of transactions per second, and can be used both as a lightweight service or embedded in your application as a library.

Next Step

The next section "Getting started with immuclient" is all about the command line interface. This section will teach you how to use immuclient to login to immudb and begin performing basic transactions.

In case you want to run the docker container yourself and only use the playground as a guideline:

docker run -d --net host -it --rm --name immudb codenotary/immudb:latest
